vCE02E2Q6m9Ytv6Lv5PgUg.text: First time to Needle & Pin the other day. The vibe when you walk in is really cool.  The walls are tiled with AstroTurf in between to make it look like gardens.  Sounds weird, but then you see the flower tiles scattered throughout, and it makes adorable sense.  Giant elephant on the wall, red phone booth -- you definitely get the English vibe.  Then the food is where you get the Indian.  Nice!  I got the lamb lollipops.  They were uh-mazing.  I should have gotten the bigger portion, for sure.  My cocktail was good, too.  I had a Gin Ricky.  (Gin is their thing.)  It was good.  It wasn't the best I've had, kind of on the tart side, but it was good.  My friend had the blackberry bramble, and the grilled cheese w/ tomato bisque.  She said both were excellent.  Then we got dessert.  Meh.  They don't have a dessert menu, and they only had one choice.  It was a banana bread with butternut squash ice cream.  It.  Was.  Weird.  It was almost like that weird stuffing you'd get at your obscure relative's house over the holidays when you were a kid.  Like, it had a very, extremely, ridiculously dense texture.  It was moist, but REALLY heavy.  I like light and fluffy, cake-like banana bread.  This was precisely the opposite.  The ice cream, I did not eat.  I don't like squash, so I can't tell you if it was good or not.  If I'd recommend improvements, it would definitely be in the dessert area.  I get that you don't want to be a bakery, but at least have a few good choices.  Also, they could turn the lights up a bit.  I guess hipsters don't need light...?

ob9lsGAqkCBoAFTiMKoRbw.text: I'll admit, I wasn't expecting much. First, the owner gave us a thorough explanation of each menu item. Though the brunch menu is limited, there's definitely something for everyone in your party. The crew split a Bread Board and I'm so glad we did. Have you ever enjoyed a freshly made bagel? I remember visiting Bageland in Squirrel Hill as a kid, and that's the closest I can get to that flavor. Between our group we ordered the Bangers and Mash (looked awesome though on the small side), a Popover (much heartier than expected), Oat Cakes and Overnight Oats (one of the most delicious breakfast items I've tried in my life). When my trio of Oat Cakes arrived it looked good, but I assumed I would demolish it in under 5 minutes. I left with two-thirds of it for what became an oat cake dinner! x5adg9TL6AYqyqlIvzk_Bg.text: This restaurant definitely hits as a fit for the new "Dormont is actually kind of cool" scene.  The food is well above average, eclectic, creative, and tasty.  Some are knock-outs, and some are average.  For example, the sauce with the chick pea dust encrusted cauliflower was top-notch... the chips that went with the fried cod: mediocre at best.  But this imperfection seems inevitable when you are trying to fuse Indian and British pub food.  The real question is--will it continue to get better?  I would call the food overall a solid 7.  (I would like to note here that this is often the case for even the most "in" restaurants--inconsistency is everywere).  The drink menu, however, is a 9+.  My guest, and others in the restaurant, were loving the mixed drinks.  $10 for a lot of creativity and kick.  I was driving, so I just had a glass of wine - which was actually quite good itself.    There is also a passion in which the servers, bartender, manager, approach the whole endeavor... I hope it is sustainable.    Decor is nice, and a little odd - just like the food.  I think this one has a pretty good chance, if it continues to evolve and stay edgy and happy.  My advice to the owners would be to view the opening of the restaurant as the beginning, not the end, of the innovations.

8bBLIVzUpmyPdqk1qvcVrQ.text: This is a great spot that has probably become my favorite for cocktails. I tend to frequent Lawrenceville more, but will make it out here periodically just because I enjoy the drinks so much. They are also probably the most creative cocktails in town at the moment. The bar is gorgeous (with twinkling lights in the counter), but I wish it was bigger. It tends to always be the most packed part of the restaurant.  I think the food is delicious here, but many of the portions are small. There really isn't an item on the menu I have not enjoyed, but the scotch eggs are probably my favorite and the best I've had. Their recent menu change has also added a greater variety of options.  During our last visit, we had some of the most friendly service. Our waiter, Shana, was very pleasant. The sous chef Marcus also greeted us and accommodated a unique request with perfection. Marcus was an absolute delight and checked back frequently to make sure we were satisfied. The kitchen, unfortunately, does not get enough credit for the tasty things they make.  Overall, I highly recommend this place. The biggest reason keeping me from giving them a 5 is that I feel the prices are just a bit too high for the portions. And while I understand paying more for a cocktail with many or unique ingredients, the more basic cocktails are still on the high end for Pittsburgh. If most items on the menu were cut by $2-$3, I think the pricing would be much more reasonable. yG-4d99Xy2QsSl6wcuMd6w.text: This is one of my absolute favorite spots in the Greater Pittsburgh Area! Being from England originally, I love a both English and Indian food... the fusion style of this restaurant is amazing. I also consider myself a gin aficionado and their gin bar has a massive collection to make a number of amazing gin cocktails.   My favorite dish, by far, is the chicken tikka grilled cheese with the tomato bisque.  The Gobi Manchurian is also AMAZING! If you love a good chicken tikka like I do, I don't recommend the chicken tikka here - only because it's a really nontraditional tikka due to the noodles and the sauce isn't too flavorful.   The vibe is very hipster and the restaurant itself is pretty dark - if you're not into that, I recommend trying to get past it to really get a taste of some awesome English-Fusion food.

Nlzp6qKAXEU7i_ot7JHGbg.text: BOTTOM LINE: just get the paneer tikka.  **Let's face it no one reads the whole review to get to the bottom line so I've placed it in the beginning to make sure you read it.   I must have passed this place hundreds of times before and never realized it for what it was rather assumed it was a high end tailor shop! So imagine my surprise/excitement when I realized this place existed.  The decor at Needle and Pin is very modernistic and hip. The aura is great and I would easily come here more often if they would transplant themselves to where Tender used to be in Lawrenceville!!! (Although can anything ever replace the amazing-ness that was Tender?) They have a full bar and a great extensive list of drinks which feature a wide selection of *gin* cocktails. Our server was very helpful and nice, even encouraging us to request cocktails made to our liking!   Food wise, I was a little let down. We ordered a few things-the Lamb lollipop, the paneer tikka, beef Wellington and the Scottish Eggs. The lamb had a lamby taste which I didn't enjoy. However, my friend thought they were great and didn't notice the gamey taste at all. I found the beef Wellington very bland and the Scottish eggs had a weird taste--I'm not sure but it tasted like they used chickpea batter to deep fry the eggs and it just didn't taste that great. Honestly, I only liked the paneer tikka because it was the most favorable dish we ordered-BUT also the most non British thing on the menu. Not to get super deep and heavy on a yelp post but I am always unsure how to feel about "British" food when so much of it is stolen bits and pieces of my culture during years of oppression and exploitation--I'm not salty about it But so isn't the beef Wellington so maybe don't order that.

We also split the main dish, a tikka masala. It's a hearty helping and really tasty. For my gluten free friends, everything I got was already naturally GF and the only thing I had to leave off was the english biscuit in the tikki masala. They actually brought out the dish with the biscuits and made me a new one, which is super kind!   The service was very friendly and prompt and I'm really looking forward to making this my neighborhood haunt.

Starting with drinks, my friend ordered the Raj Mimosa and I got the Brunch with Rita. I loved my drink so much. I felt like I could have had 5 and not gotten sick of it. The popover has curried chicken and vegetables inside with a poached egg on top, and was more of a gamble. I felt like the bagel bites were exactly what we expected (which means it was good), and the popover totally paid off (amazing!). S_orf7NJFhfe091wqWrepw.text: A cool new place for the area! Saw the idea of the British/Indian fusion and found it very interesting! Came with a couple of friends for dinner on Friday and were very pleased. The inside of the restaurant is well lit and well decorated - cool bar areas with lots of different types of gin to choose from. We were seated quickly at a booth and ordered our drinks and dinners. I got the Blackberry Bramble which was super tasty - fruity and refreshing! I also ordered the Tikka Grilled Cheese w/ Curried Coconut Tomato Bisque (such a mouthful) while my two friends both got the Tikka Masala. The food came out quickly and was fresh & hot. The friends enjoyed their Tikka Masala - spiced well and had some heat to it! The grilled cheese & bisque was also very good! The bisque was very heavy, so even though the dish didn't look huge, I was pretty stuffed!  For dessert, the two friends got the cheesecake and bread pudding. Cheesecake came wrapped in a puff pastry thing (we nicknamed it "The Cheesecake Poof") and a side of fruit puree. The cheesecake was super soft and delicious and went really well with the puff pasty! The bread pudding was very dense and well spiced! The garnishes of cranberries, raisins, and dates were also a nice touch.   Experience was very good overall! Service was relatively quick and very friendly. The food didn't blow me away but was definitely enjoyable, and I'd be interested in visiting again to try more dishes. A bit more expensive than a casual dinner, but a nice place to go for something a little more special. Given the unique menu, Needle and Pin would also be a great place to bring out of town-ers!

h1TvA638gj0DWm9zysHIYw.text: I wish it was possible to give three and a half stars - this place really wasn't bad at all. We LOVED the Scotch Eggs and Cumin Crusted Lamb Lollipops. Tons of flavor and a great size for a small plate.   My husband ordered the beef tenderloin and it was no bigger than the appetizers we'd just eaten. While the sweet potatoes and chili gastritis were both amazing, the beef was slightly underdone and was just far too small to be considered a main entree, especially for the price we paid for it. I understand that it's a recent trend to serve small portions, but this just left him hungry and it was not worth the cost.   I got the seared scallop soup while and the broth and scallops were delicious, my rice was extremely underdone. It wasn't just al dente, it was crunchy and retained no flavor from the amazing broth.   Because we were both starving, we wound up ordering beef Wellington at the end of the meal. While we're always happy to taste our way through a menu, we shouldn't have had to do this out of hunger for the prices we were paying. The Wellington was also underdone and these flavors sadly weren't there. The puff pastry wasn't cooked and left the dish soggy. It's a Gin bar and neither my husband or I are big gin fans, but i still loved my Hell or High Water and would come back for it.

y2kLkkf3JIvP9d0Zc_zdgw.text: Needle and Pin proves Victorious when challenged with the Dreaded Double Date!!!      First off, the cocktails here, for me, are the stars of the show. They have an incredible Gin menu, and they definitely know how to use it. If you like a little kick with your libations I would highly recommend the Hell or High-water, it was fantastic.     The food was very good, but there is definitely better Indian cuisine in Pittsburgh, however, I don't know of any other Indian/British restaurants that have the ambiance that Needle and Pin has, so if you're craving Tikka Masala, but also want a craft cocktail than the N&P just might be your spot. The Scotch eggs are delicious, I really enjoyed the Chili paneer with naan, and the Lamb Lollipops were wonderful, although they were served with cold vermicelli and some flaky pastry that were unimpressive. Also, my girlfriend and I Love Gobi Manchurian, but this was probably our least favorite dish of the evening.     Lastly, the biggest flaw of this dining experience was how painfully slow it took to get our food. Our reservation was for 7 and we didn't leave until after 10. Luckily we were really enjoying each others company, but man that could have really sucked if we were with people we didn't like. The restaurant was relatively empty, and they have been open long enough that you'd think they'd have the kinks worked out.     To summarize, if you're really craving great Indian food, I would recommend somewhere more authentic like Tamarind in Green Tree. If you're looking for trendy with great cocktails, this place delivers. Don't go with people you dislike, because you might be here awhile.

a9b1vBG6uiaSXiV0HbT6RA.text: This place gets most things right--great service, expertly-made delicate cocktails, a unique and well-executed menu, great music and ambiance. i7AbEZCHK5zcMvjsYntKaw.text: Let me preface this by saying that I work in the service industry. I totally get having kinks when a restaurant first opens. But there were so many problems all across the board that I am not sure it's possible to right this ship.  Normally, I write a narrative review. That would take up too much time for both of us, so I'm going to list the problems that my group and I had:  1) Service. It was terrible.They apologized and said that they were short staffed. But there was ZERO urgency on behalf of the staff. None. Our waiter, who was doubling as host, seemed to just amble around, not doing much of either task. It took us about 10 minutes to get water. 10 minutes for him to come back to take our drink orders. When the drinks came out after about another 10 minutes, he didn't bring mine. I figured he was on his way back to grab it. NOPE, He returned after about 10 MORE minutes to see if we were ready to order food. At that point, I mentioned my drink. Which he then went back to grab, It was a bramble. There was no stirrer, no straw. So it was gin on the top, blackberry at the bottom. Also, the waiter blamed me not getting my entree on the POS system (er...don't you enter it into the system). Eveyrone was done eating before they got it out to me (really? How long does it take to make grilled cheese....especially since the forgotten order should have been bumped up to first on the list, as it is in EVERY RESTAURANT IN WHICH I'VE WORKED). We ended up asking them to forget it.  2) Food: Neither Anglo, nor Indian. Everything was so sweet. Except for the Curry Pot Pie, which was nearly inedible due to saltiness. The Chilli Paneer was not bad, but was Thai in flavor profile. Foodwise, our meal was one gigantic disappointment.   3) Drinks: There is no gin menu. Repeat. NO GIN MENU. They tout carrying 80 gins, but can't be bothered with providing a menu for the patrons. This is something that takes 2 minutes to create as, ostensibly, they have a list of their gins on their inventory sheet. Cocktails sounded interesting, but were mediocre at best. And, again - served with no stirrers.  4) Bleach - If you still dare to go here, sit in the dining room. The tables to the side of the bar kept getting hit with nostril burning bleach waves from the bar sink.   5) Ambiance. Meh  We expressed our disappointment to the staff. At no time did a manager come over to speak with us.   I would love for Needle & Pin to turn this around. But it's so much more than just first week kinks. Bad food. Mediocre Drinks. It doesn't bode well.
